kelvin90701

Guns are banned, now what?
 
 1) Gun confiscation? 
 
 The government just takes them away? That is property confiscation and unconstitutional. You may call it confiscation. I call it stealing. The government just takes your property and gives you no compensation? Yep that is stealing. It is never a good idea to let the government take the property of good people. Especially since I have broken no law, committed no crime. You may argue that I broke the law by just keeping my guns, but the government manufactured me into a criminal. I was not a criminal before the ban, now I am retroactive criminal? Maybe you agree with criminalizing firearm ownership, well this is what happens: http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/england/2248511.stm . Good men get locked up with rapist and murders, and are ruined. 
 
 
 2) Gun buy back?
 
 A well made personal defense handgun starts at about $300. Custom rifles can be more than $3000. I have only one .22 that starts at $225. My other firearms are between $800 and $1500. Granted junk Saturday night specials can be between $50-150. Collectable firearms are priceless.
 
 There are 230 million firearms in this country. If the government just pays an average of $100 for every firearm, that is 23 BILLION dollars. You will never get Congress to allocate 23 billion dollars. They back stab each other for 10 million dollars.
 
 Both ideas are just dumb.

post_info.post_title: OK you pass the law, guns are banned.  Now what?

enfant terrible

Guns are banned, now what?
 
 1) Gun confiscation? 
 
 (...)
 
 2) Gun buy back?

 
 Why either of those?
kelvin90701

Why either of those?

 
 That is the way the UK, Aussies, and Canada get's rid of guns. That's how it will happen here. Unless you have a better idea. There are only two ways to get them off the street:
 
 1) Just take them, no questions asked.
 
 2) Buy them back.
 
 Option number 1 is one step closer to a police state.
 
 Option number 2 will ruin the economy and is close as you can get to burning money. When the government builds an aircraft carrier. It puts skilled people to work and buys hi-tech gear that keeps all sorts of industries around the country working. Plus it collects taxes again from all the employment it creates. At 4.5 billion dollars per aircraft carrier, we can build 5 more with 230 billion dollars. With a gun buy back, then what do you? You melt the guns = burning money. Remember 230 billion dollars was a very very very low estimate.
 
 Both ideas are just plain dumb.
kelvin90701

Here is what happened in Canada:
 
 http://www.cnsnews.com/ForeignBureaus/archive/200212/FOR20021204f.html
 
 "Auditor General Sheila Fraser was quoted as calling the $1 billion estimate an "astronomical cost overrun" from the original price tag. "
 
 
 They did not even try to take them off the street. All they tried was to collect names and addresses. How much will it cost to acutally buy them back? How about more than an astronomical amount is a good guess.
enfant terrible

That is the way the UK, Aussies, and Canada get's rid of guns.

 
 Man, you've inhaled... I happen to live in Canada right now (and for the last 2 years). Canada has not gotten rid of existing guns at all. You just can't buy or import new ones. I think you also cannot resell old guns, but you can keep any that you already have.
 
 And of course, this applies only to handguns. Hunting weapons are perfectly legal.

Man, you've inhaled... I happen to live in Canada right now (and for the last 2 years). Canada has not gotten rid of existing guns at all. You just can't buy or import new ones. I think you also cannot resell old guns, but you can keep any that you already have.

 250,000 gun owners in Toronto. Only 1,700 volunteered for the $50. Why did the boy part of $850? Could it be fear of the government? Why would good people have to fear the government?

 Although enfant terrible doesn't make much sense here, it does bring up a third idea and that is to still buy back the guns but at a much lower cost.
 
 I'm not for any of these ideas. The right to own weapons makes sense in the US. One day it will be inevitable that our entire nation will be caught up in some sort of conflict and the war will be here. On that day I want our enemies to know that every single person in the country is a potential soldier and has a weapon to use against them.
 
 Also if something goes horribly wrong and somehow we are sent back to the stone age (post nuclear strikes) people are going to need guns to survive and gather food.
 
 I believe that allowing our population to have guns is the best way to ensure that our nation can survive anything. The side affects are not that pleasant such as murder and other crimes, but the guns are still not even the problem in the case. People are the problem. And perhaps even that problem can be fixed without having to give up guns.

I'm sure a great deal of security measures would become redundant if guns were no longer owned by anyone and the police force would have a far easier time policing people who didn't have guns (sniper weapons). I don't know how much this would save per year but just maybe it would save enough over time that the government would implement a plan to buy back all guns at full price, only gathering a few per year for perhaps 10 years. That could be an option as well although they would have to make sure people are not going out and buying new guns during this time.
